comments.commentBody:
@AAC

It would be one thing if this video was done in a thoughtful manner that shed any light on Islam. Please do not hide behind the "protecting free speech" umbrella and call this video what it is: HATE SPEECH.

And THAT is not a value that I espouse as an American.
George Gagner:  Do you share Mitt Romney's passion for Israel?  If so that makes a total of one other country whose citizens would have your consent to occupy the same planet as these United States.

AAC, Obama did not elevate religious tolerance over freedom of speech.  He did NOT say anything against free speech.  We all see instances of people we'd like to muzzle, but we don't because we believe in the Bill of Rights.  We also believe in freedom of religion but lately that has been challenged a lot more than freedom of speech.  The religious right and conservative base of the Republican party has been very intolerant of the religious freedom of anyone who isn't Christian or who doesn't share their particular Christian beliefs.  Why not chastise those people rather than the defenders of free speech AND freedom of religion!

Four years ago John McCain was calling Mr. Obama a foreign-policy naif (or words to that effect) and, technically, he was correct. Mr. Obama, on the other hand, refrained from making stupid remarks that would have demonstrated that naivete to such an extent as to convince a majority of his fellow citizens that he wouldn't be able to handle the intricacies of foreign affairs.  Mr. Romney, however, just can't help himself.  Russia is our enemy, China is a cheat, the Brits can't run an Olympics properly and all Europeans are Socialists who have nothing of value to offer this exceptional land of ours (including the benefits of universal health care and gun control). Mexico is full of...Mexicans, all of whom want to crash the border and take away whatever jobs people like Willard don't export overseas. And sensitivity towards matters of faith among Muslims in the Middle East obviously doesn't rate as highly or as favorably as the devotion displayed by the region's  Christians and Jews.  I'd love to see this man make a campaign stop at a mosque at some point.  In any event, he clearly doesn't have the faculties for this aspect of the job that he's been auditioning for.

Oh, WP, you're drinking too much left-wing blogsite talking points Kool-Aid (plus authoring a non-trivial number yourself).

The latest proposal of Ryan's on Medicare, that Romney has embraced, calls for an option to select traditional Medicare. Nice try.

The so-called non-partisan Tax Policy Center isn't citing Romney plans to increase taxes on the middle class: it's merely their ASSUMPTION that the only way he can fund all the tax reductions he DOES propose at the higher income brackets is to hit the middle class. Yet, a ton of economists have said otherwise, and his plans actually call for a 20% reduction in taxes across the board. Nice try.

As regards defense, when you're trying to save defense capacity in the face of the draconian demands of sequestration (and you remember how poorly our defense and intelligence capabilities stood at 9/11, resulting from Clinton cuts), you start high and are willing to compromise -- sequestration remains in place, and SOMEONE has to defend the defense side, as the president clearly has gone fishin', despite the current and last defense secretaries' warnings about the extent of impending cuts.

As to what he would cut, right back at 'ya: how would Mr. Obama re-ignite demand (ignored for his entire presidency)? How would he jump-start hiring (related to demand -- also ignored)? Where would he TAKE us (completely unanswered)?

More than Mr. Obama can play the close-to-the-vest game on details. But perhaps the debates, on both sides.

To JL:

Guess what? Medicare is projected (by its own trustees) to be bankrupt in just a few years; and Democrats aren't getting new taxes to avoid the need to transform it into something strategically viable. Bottom line: we need to spend a lot less on it. Medicaid is bankrupting our states, and there is no appeitite for massive new taxes at that level, either. The only people offering rational plans for saving these programs are Republicans -- Democrats see the eternal solution as merely taxing more (and changing less), when we ALREADY consume 24% of GDP at the federal level, amass $trilion-plus annual deficits, and even liberal solons are warning that we're crowding out private investment by this unconscionable governmentalization of all things known to man.

Yes, I think we need more tax cuts now. So does Romney and most Republicans. It's pro-growth.

Mr. Obama SHOULD be cutting more federal jobs than his predecessor: Dubya wasn't dealing with the effects of the Great Recession, with the private sector (that SUSTAINS the public sector) not hiring. He should have cut far MORE federal jobs.

Romney isn't down -- among likely voters, he's still at 48%-49%, in Mr. Obama's favor. And I expect that as the jobs situation continues to deteriorate, as projected by analysts for the fourth quarter, that he'll be pulling ahead. Back to my original response to WP: that Mr. Obama hasn't been able to put distance between them is because people realize that his plans don't work.
I think you meant to say, President Obama did not get a bounce out of the Democratic Party Convention, for Romney is back in the lead less than a week after the Charlotte event ended.

It is no surprise that Romney did not get a bounce out of the Republican National Convention. The problem for Romney is that the Convention provided the American people with an opportunity to get a better sense of what today's GOP stands for. And once the American people know what the GOP stands for (abolishing Medicare, raising taxes on the middle class in order to cut them for the wealthy, increasing the military budget, etc.) they are far less likely to view the GOP favorably.

The lack of popularity of the GOP agenda is the primary reason why Romney and his allies are trying so hard to make sure that Romney's positions are never subject to public review. That is why Romney and the rest of the GOP refuse to provide basic information about Romney's tax plans, jobs plans, foreign policy positions, etc. And it is why the GOP is trying so hard to suppress voting among Democratic leaning groups throughout the country.

The GOP realizes that if an educated public is allowed to vote, the Republicans will get demolished in November. As a result, they are trying their best to make sure that people do not get educated about what the GOP stands for, and to keep Democrats from being able to vote. That is not the strategy of a party that feels confident about the policies they are proposing.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236
Cognitive impairment around menopause? Try learning something new, go on the internet, take up a sport...

We females want to know: if DHT is necessary for neurogenesis (in men, or in male rats), what does this mean for women? Do we also produce DHT in our brains after exercise?

Do estrogens also enhance neurogenesis? And if so, do decreases in estrogen explain the cognitive impairment some of us experience around menopause -- or can one still produce estrogen in the brain even after one's ovaries don't?

Whoa whoa whoa.

Anyone who starred in "Friday Night Lights" is exempt from being a flop. Love that show. Okay but yeah, his movies are terrible.

I don't know what's so fancy about DUNKS either. I get what the clue is getting at, but 'fancy' isn't quite what I'd call it. Showy?

replies.commentBody: That line always cracked me up, too!

comments.commentBody: "Are You My Mother?" was my favorite children's book, not as a child, but as a mother.  I think my kids got pretty tired of it, and me laughing every time I read the line:  "You are not my mother, you are a snort"

@ Viv: I thought the same thing, and that would be a fresher theme, IMO. Why? BECAUSE. When? ANYTIME. Where? NYTXWP. What? QUESTION/ANSWERTHEME. Who? NOT SOMEONE WHO I USUALLY HAVE TROUBLE WITH. (MOL, resist the urge to tell me it's "whom", even if it isn't.)

I did enjoy the riddle, and the solving was smooth. I was quite relieved that 64A was NEESON, because if it were KITSCH, the comments would be full of insults. (As if other actors haven't been in giant flops in the past.)

P.D. EASTMAN, author of "Are You My Mother?" and "Go, Dog, Go!" is a real person, not an alias of Dr. Seuss. I'll accept Linda Mccartney's maiden name since it's at least fresh. This photography guy, however, needs to be put on the shelf indefinitely.

I get my news from Comedy Central, which someone is probably going to pass of as a MONTAGE of people getting SCOOPED.

I'm no basketball expert, but since when are DUNKS "fancy"? That reminds me of that discriminatory basketball league that got publicity a year or two ago.
I agree. Women should consider taking low dose testosterone creams -- libido, sensation, energy levels, and muscle mass/strength.

Both 'compounds' as you say are extremely powerful chemicals and do a whole lot more than what you listed, like enhancing growth of tumour cells and yet unknown cellular level changes.  You are willingly participating in a grand human experiment with the results to be known in say a generation.  Good luck with all those things that 'go up'...

Anecdote re more than one post-menopausal F taking low-dose testosterone and vaginal estrogen:  cognition, affection, sensation, and libido all go up if both compounds are taken, not with either alone.
Deadline, glad it wasn't worse, and sorry that you had such a time of it.

If you have chronic tennis elbow, some exercises may be too "advanced" to start with right away.  I had a very low grade right tennis elbow--maybe from tennis + poor ergonomics--for about 18 years and then many sessions of acupunture helped it, plus, I'm guessing, fish oil.  However, then my left elbow became very painful for over the past 18 month, even waking me almost nightly. What has really made a big difference is a combination of chiropractic coupled with protocol of 3 different cold laser treatments. I'm almost ready for exercises now and it's been about 7-8 sessions.
The "close election" qualification only represents 3000 of  the 30000 simulations the overall forecast is based upon.

Here are a few interactive computational solutions for the cases of sliding against tree, pulled away from tree (Gary #11), acrobatic dual slide (Gary #11), and tropical slide on curved palm tree (Giovanni #29). Cat can be repositioned on ladder (Sam #14). No velocity considerations... yet?
http://www.geogebratube.org/material/show/id/17193

we are only looking at this current dispute with a microscope. do not try to distract us with other things, so called expansionism.

you said 100 years ago the islands became part of Okinawa. How did you do it ?

your pocket book point is brilliant.

Please continue.

maybe you need learn more stories, that will be helpful to you. DiaoYu Islands disputes exist for 40 years, China government and Japan government got one agreement, that no one be allowed to land these islands. they keep this agreement for 40 years, and put disputes aside and for good relationship of 2 country.
now it's japan government break the agreement, decide to purchase these islands. i am sure even you live in Japan, you also do not know its country.

really like what you said.

Only people with a conscience will say so. After all it is a matter of right and wrong and who is the rightful owner.
I am impressed by the integrity shown by these Japanese scholars in your link.  They are the only remaining hope for Japan.

Being American, not sure why our govt decision to back Japanese rightest revival of militarism / fascism.
Even Japanese professor states Japan stole the islands from China and some how colluded with US to get it back... http://www.skycitygallery.com/japan/diaohist.html

It's not about money, it's about Japanese govt continued denial of the atrocities done to Chinese / Koreans / Asians... And now slapping the faces of Chinese by claiming land that they once obtained by military invasion.

I hope all Americans read the article and ask ourselves why we are supporting a govt which was basically Hitler in Asia.

It's like some riot group came and took your home, then police came and put down the riot... But later the police conspired with the rioters and gave them part of your house??? Doesn't make sense right? But that's what happened...
I am sorry to break the news to you but "cold sores" are lesions of herpes simplex 1.

You see, Mr. Obama has had over 3 years to 'do his job.' And yet, even with the murder of OBL, the world is far worse off than those awful Bush years. You like a nuclear weapon in Iran? Maybe you should go back to do some math and figure how many people will die because of these failed policies. Oh, it will happen when a Republican will be President so it is won't be Obama's fault. Like when Clinton was getting a blowjob instead of paying attention to the Cole bombing. Or blaming Reagan for the failed policy of Carter, who now is a world expert in foreign affairs. Maybe the one who needs to do some homework is actually, you!
At least he is saying something beside, "I'm sorry".

EreyaG, speaking of homework, have your studies led you to conclude that North Korean nukes don't go "boom"? Now, who's watch would that have been on? Hint: There's a W in his name.

We understand that you are hurt that your candidate is dropping in the polls, and has shot himself in the foot trying to get his diplomatic credentials out of the holster--which isn't going to help, either.

Calm down and rest assured that we are most certainly doing better than in a world where our home values were plummeting, the DJIA was at 6500, our largest industries were failing and we were suffering the loss of nearly 900,000 jobs a month. Take a deep breath. We haven't had more astute international leaders in the White House and State Department in perhaps a century.

During these last two weeks since his coronation was bestowed without the typical bounce in his poll numbers, Willard has gone from pathetic to despicable.  Can anyone outside of his immediate family continue to regard him as presidential material?  Instead of flapping his lips prematurely and spitefully without taking the time to sort out the facts of a horrible incident or the nature of his opponent's response, Witless Mitt should let the incumbent do his job and attend to his math homework.
I'm sure within days there will be plenty of 3rd-party accessory makers with cheaper adapters for $10 or even less.
Your ignorance isn't saying much here, buddy.  As a white person, I am actually shocked that people are saying such racist things.  This guy is a disgrace.
I believe the content of this article and the commentary speak to the artistic integrity of Simone's performance. Ms. Jones doesn't want to see herself; she wants the story to be told accurately.

Steven 322, the issue is not that she is light skinned but rather that she does not look like Nina Simone. Imaging casting Rashida Jones, Quincy Jones’ daughter to play a role based on Nicole Kidman. She's a good actress, (Rashida) but looks nothing like Kidman. That's the question: are you not supposed to at least be reminded of Nina Simone when you're watching the movie?

Steven 322, you are clearly no fully informed - there was an extensive controversy about the MKL sculpture, specifically because it failed to accurately capture the spirit of the man; the sculpture portrayed him standing intransigently with his arms folded and looking not peaceful but more intolerant and ready to fight. In addition, the quote on the sculpture was taken out of context and actually had to be changed because it conveyed an equally inaccurate message.

Actually, the MLK sculpture is a really good analogy for the Nina Simone issue, and why Saldana shouldn't play her - clearly the sculptor of the MLK memorial got the spirit of the man WRONG. No matter his race or creed, he clearly simply couldn't/didn't understand what the job required. Likewise, given what Simone stood for - or rather against - a purely commercial and aesthetic choice, like Saldana, violates everything that Simone was: decidedly and deliberately anti-establishment, questioning and destroying the popular aesthetic for women and art, and decrying overtly commercial choices.

The hypocrisy is so thick it's dripping off my computer screen.

Jennifer Lawrence as Katniss? Not as dark as we imagined her, Zoe Saldana? Too light skinned, regardless of their acting abilities.

Or let me bring up a different example, Lei Yixin a master sculptor was commissioned to do the Martin Luther King jr statue in the national mall in Wasington. People criticised the choice, not because of his credentials but because he was Chinese. Why couldn't they have picked a african-american, or at least a American.

I thought judging someone by their character or abilities and not their skin color was the right way to go. But there's caveats apparently.

The thing is though it's a no-win situation. Let's say from now on every fashion magazine, every tv show, every movie started casting only the darkest skinned african-americans would Tiffani Jones and all the other bloggers like her be satisfied? No. She'd proabably say something like "Oh look at the white media trying to only use the most stereotypical looking blacks to portray people of color, our light skinned sisters and brothers have historically always been invisible to whites".

Once you have that cynical, angry worldview that everyone is out to disrespect you and your group (whether it's gender, ethnic or class) then the world becomes a giant rorschach test. You only see what you want to see that confirms your biases.

I'm sorry...but WHAT?? This is part of the problem. NINA SIMONE WAS STUUUUUUUUNNING. The media picked Saldana because she is the representation of what white media has chose to portray as the "acceptable" image of blackness. If a woman is full blooded, TRULY dark skinned, has prominent african features ... she is not considered "beautiful" enough for media to give her representation in the public space.
So Donald...you are part of the problem. YOu are part of the reason why most people can't name more than 5 DARK skinned, PURELY black--NOT biracial--women who are recognized internationally in Hollywood.
The woman was STUNNING. Just because she wasn't YOUR pitiful, brainwashed, COMPLETELY media controlled image of beauty---doesn't mean that the woman was a striking vision of black beauty.

I don't think Zoe Saldana is that pretty...but we know that having light or white skin makes people ignore what your actual facial features look like.

Lauryn Hill would be amazing if she could keep the crazy at bay for long enough.

I get your point, despite the rather unfortunate wording of your first sentence.

"Emergency Ward!," regardless of its oddness, blew me away when it came out my freshman year in college (in Northern Wisconsin; Ashland, of all places). It opened my eyes, not only to the rest of Nina's catalogue, but to a whole new world of music as well. She was a unique talent, and it would be wrong to not cast an actress who can properly portray her as such.
nina simone was not beautiful  to look at. her beauty came from her gut her pain her soul do not  cast anyone w/o those qualities
Each country's reaction is unconnected to the other's. But one thing is a given. Attack the prophet, riots happen.

@Bryan:
It's not as hard to understand as you make it out to be. The Likud Bloc, which Netanyahu heads, is the right wing of Israel's political spectrum. Not only is there a natural affinity for conservatives on this side of the water (especially given Netanyahu's personal ties to Bain and Romney), but the funadmentalist Christian bloc over here supports Israel for an entirely different reason: its place in the apocalypitc end-of-days scenario. In this, Armageddon starts with war in the Holy Land. And who better to produce that scenario than Mittens and Bibi, together after Romney stuck his foot in his mouth at the Olympics, by showing up in Israel to noisily rattle a saber at Iran.
As for your astonishment at events in Egypt, the entire neo-con meme in this country that got us involved in Iraq was to midwife democracy in the middle east. And those same neocons are shocked, shocked (!) that the Muslim Brotherhood won a free, unfettered election in Egypt. But that wasn't the neo-con plan, they whine.
As for hewing to the policy of "mutually assured destruction," well you're either hopelessly obtuse, or risibly naive. Nobody in the Common Era has been able to control Afghanistan, though many have tried. Did that stop the neocons? Of course not. We're exceptional! We can do anything. And now we're in Afghanistan longer than the Soviets were. Oops! And with suicide tactics coming more to the fore, what makes you think MAD has a chance of working. It doesn't, not in the least.

It seems that Obama had every right to make an important speech in Cairo early in his administration; this should not have been a red flag to Israel in itself. We need good working relationships with Israel AND with Arab nations in the region.

Bibi's actions to leverage influence in the US elections is an outrage. Frankly, Israel can go it alone if this is the tack they take. "With friends like that..." Yes, Bibi is old friends with Romney--that alone makes it all scarier. Seeing Romney's off-target response to the deaths in Libya, imaging the pair of them together wielding the club in American foreign policy should make everyone's blood run cold.

As you are indeed aware Mr Keller, though you did not refer to the matter, there has been a long standing icy coldness between President Obama and Bibi Netanyahu. Considering the long history of the close and mutually respectful relationship between the US and Israel, it has always puzzled me why from the get go these two gentlemen have been unable to simply respect their differences yet consider the bigger picture of Israel located in a sea of Arab hatred from the very beginning in 1947/48 and that the US has been its faithful friend and guarantor during all that time, which it is clear a majority of Americans wish to see continue.

Is it possible that from the time that President Obama delivered his Cairo speech in 2009 that Israel has become worried regarding US intentions ? Or has that speech and subsequent outreach, such as aid to the Libyan rebels, and the withdrawal of support from President Mubarak of Egypt and subsequent support of the Moslem Brotherhood leadership there, led to further Israeli concerns ?

Now that the events of 09/11/2012 in Libya and Egypt shocked the US is it possible that our policy in that part of the world needs to be refined ? It may be a very good idea for the two leaders to meet and discuss their concerns soon.

With regard to Iran, the Israeli position, as I have previously mentioned, in the Mad Mullahs column, can easily accommodate itself to the policy which worked so well for the US and the USSR. MAD, Mutually Assured Destruction.

I have family in Zhengzhou, Henan, China and Shanghai, China, both places where Foxconn assembles iPhones. None of my extended family have ever told me that Foxconn uses child labor or "virtual slave labor". The monthly starting pay at the Zhengzhou, Henan factory is almost what my uncle makes in a year, farming in my family's ancestral village less than an hour away.

You do realize that most tech companies also use Foxconn to assemble their products? Are you also boycotting them?
?. My first comment is about today's puzzle.  My response to Dr. W is just that, a response.

I raise my glass to you, Peter! More well-deserved recognition for one of the most accomplished journalist lenses of our times. Wonderful, wonderful stuff here. Bravo!

- Ken Tanaka -

A great tribute to a great photographer and great human being.
Congratulations, Peter!
Helene,...your poetic response is the child born of art.  I am in love with that child as if it were my own.

I am struck by two prominent themes seen in the slide show: the access to Soviet/barely post-Soviet spaces and refugees - two areas of humanity that are still largely invisible or too easily forgotten in America, and two areas that are routinely impacting America without much understanding. These images are incredible for their timing not only of the lens shutter but also of the human shudder that Mr. Turnley seems to have controlled to record these haunting and historic human moments.
